questions.text: What is the most common endocrine tumor of the pancreas?
questions.solution:
The most common functioning endocrine tumor of the pancreas is insulinoma. It is a tumor arising from the beta cells of the pancreas.

The most common malignant functional neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is gastrinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about insulinoma is false?

choices.text: Majority of insulinomas are benign and solitary
Insulinomas occur more commonly in females
Insulinomas occur more commonly in the tail, than in the head and body of pancreas
Mean age at diagnosis is 45 years

questions.solution:
Insulinomas are dis­tributed equally throughout the pancreas, despite the predominance of beta-cells in the body and tail.

The majority (90%) of insulinomas are benign and solitary, and only 10% are malignant and multifocal. Malignant insulinomas are usually found in association with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome. Insulinomas are typically small, with an average size of 1.0 to 1.5 cm.

Insulinomas occur more commonly in females, between 40–60 years of age with the mean age of diagnosis at 45 years.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Whipple's triad?

choices.text: Symptoms of hypoglycaemia after fasting or exercise
Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose

questions.solution:
Elevated plasma levels of insulin is not a component of the triad. Whipple's triad is a clinical condition characterised by an insulin-producing tumour of the pancreas called insulinoma. 

The components of the triad are:

  • Symptoms of hypoglycaemia after fasting or exercise.
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L.
  • Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose.

Patients with insulinoma eat frequently to avoid hypoglycemic symptoms. Hence, weight loss is not a feature of insulinoma.

questions.text: The gold standard test for the diagnosis of insulinoma is ______.
questions.solution:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of insulinoma is the 72-hour monitored fasting test.

In this test, the levels of blood glucose, insulin, proinsulin, C peptide are measured in 1 to 2-hour intervals. When done so, a patient with insulinoma will have higher values of insulin, proinsulin, and C peptide which are expected to decrease in a normal person in response to the hypoglycemia due to fasting.

All patients should be advised to undergo surgical excision of insulinoma following the exclusion of diffuse abdominal metastases by ultrasound or CT scan.

questions.text: A 50-year-old previously healthy man presents to the clinic with complaints of episodic palpitations, sweating, and giddiness which are relieved with food or fruit juices. Laboratory investigations are suggestive of insulinoma. Which of the following will be the best imaging modality to localize the site of the tumor in this patient?
questions.solution:
Intra-operative ultrasound is the best method in localizing the site of the insulinoma. 

This is a dynamic imaging modality that provides interactive and timely information during surgical procedures. This is essential for the identification of small tumors, especially within the pancreatic head or uncinate process.

Preoperatively, the site of the tumor can be assessed by endoscopic ultrasound or CT scan.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with recurrent attacks of dizziness and abdominal pain for 3 months. Fasting blood glucose level was 40 mg%, and insulin levels were elevated. CT abdomen showed a well-defined 1 cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. The treatment plan should be _______.
questions.solution:
Recurrent hypoglycemic symptoms (dizziness) and low blood glucose with elevated insulin is suggestive of insulinoma. Tumour enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.

Insulinomas of <2 cm in diameter without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. 

Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:

  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct

Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals, octreotide or diazoxide.

questions.text: A young man with parathyroid hyperplasia and pituitary adenoma is diagnosed with multiple tumors in Passaro's triangle. Which of the following structures are constituents of the triangle?

choices.text: Superior and descending duodenum, head of the pancreas, lymph nodes
Superior duodenum, head of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach
Third part of the duodenum, body of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach
Body of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach, lesser curvature of stomach

questions.solution:
The patient is most likely suffering from MEN 1 syndrome. Gastrinoma is the most common functional entero-pancreatic tumor in MEN1. Superior and descending duodenum, head of the pancreas, and lymph nodes constitute the anatomical area called gastrinoma triangle, also known as the Passaro's triangle.

The triangle is bounded by the lines connecting:

  • The cystic duct
  • The junction between the second and third portions of the duodenum
  • The junction between the neck and body of the pancreas.

More than 70% of the gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome and most sporadic gastrinomas are located in the first and second part of the duodenum. 

Pancreatic gastrinomas are mainly observed in sporadic diseases and are mostly found in the head of the pancreas.

questions.text: What is the most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the duodenum.

Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor in MEN 1 syndrome, arising from the G cells of the pancreas. Gastrinoma, associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcers, is called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The majority of gastrinomas occur in the gastrinoma (Passaro's) triangle.

In MEN 1, they often occur in patients <30 years. Patients present with abdominal pain (the most common symptom), diarrhea and steatorrhea. 

Management: 

  • Medical management for tumors <2 cm with proton-pump inhibitors. 
  • Surgery for tumors >2 cm.
  • Proton-pump inhibitors with somatostatin analogues for advanced locoregional disease or metastasis.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text: A patient who had been suffering from chronic esophageal reflux and diarrhea is diagnosed with multiple gastrinomas. All of the following statements are true regarding his condition except _______.

choices.text: This occurs more commonly in males
More than 60% of tumors are malignant
Surgical exploration is indicated in all patients without metastasis

questions.solution:
Gastrinoma/Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a non–beta islet cell tumor of the pancreas.  

Option A: ZES is more common in males than in females.  

Option B: At the time of diagnosis, >60% of tumors are malignant. 

Option D: Surgical exploration should be performed in all patients without diffuse metastases, to remove known malignant and benign tumors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with chronic abdominal pain was brought to the casualty in a dehydrated state due to multiple diarrheal episodes. He was started on IV fluids and analgesics. On further investigation, multiple ulcers were seen in the second and third part of the duodenum and his serum gastrin concentration was 2000 pg/ml. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with this condition?

choices.text: Improvement of diarrhoea following nasogastric aspiration
Reduced basal to maximal acid output ratio

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome/gastrinoma. Here, the basal acid output (BAO) is increased. Hence, the BAO:MAO ratio is increased.

In these patients, there is gastrin hypersecretion that stimulates gastric acid secretion. This leads to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Abdominal pain is the most common complaint in these patients. However, diarrhea can occur due to:

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

Gastric pH <2.5 and a serum gastrin concentration >1000 pg/mL confirm the diagnosis of Zollinger Ellison syndrome. 

If the diagnosis remains in doubt, a secretin stimulation test is done. In this test, the fasting gastrin level is measured before secretin (2 IU/kg) is administered intravenously, and subsequent samples are obtained 2, 5, 10, and 20 minutes. Gastrin levels >200 pg/mL after administration of secretin are suggestive of gastrinoma.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: A patient who is recently diagnosed with Zollinger-Elison syndrome is started on proton pump inhibitors. There is no previous history of acid-reduction procedure done. The target basal acid output should be less than ______.
questions.solution:
The proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) dosage should be titrated to keep basal acid output <10 mEq/hr in this patient.

The target BAO is <5 mEq/hr if the patient has had a prior acid-reducing procedure. 

Ideally, the dose of proton pump inhibitors is titrated using acid output in order to improve the healing rate of peptic ulcer disease, and to avert its complications.

questions.text: Which of the following would be the preoperative imaging study of choice in patients with gastrinoma?
questions.solution:
Currently, the preoperative imaging study of choice for gastrinoma is somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (octreotide scan).

The majority of the gastrinomas are found within the Passaro’s triangle and can be detected by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS). However, it still misses many of the smaller lesions, and may confuse normal lymph nodes for gastrinomas.

If there is no tumor visible on EUS, a somatostatin receptor study is useful in identifying the location. When the pretest probability of gastrinoma is high, the sensitivity and specificity of this modality are almost 100%.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false about non-functioning pancreatic endocrine tumors?

choices.text: Most of the tumors are malignant
They account for 60-90% of all pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
They have a much better prognosis than functioning tumors

questions.solution:
Non-functioning pancreatic endocrine tumors (NF-PETs) have a worse prognosis compared to functioning tumors.

They account for 60-90% of all neuroendocrine tumors. They are usually larger (>5cm), solitary, mostly in the head of the pancreas, malignant and metastatic. These do not cause any clinical symptoms. 

They stain positive for immunohistochemical markers such as synaptophysin, chromogranin A (CgA), and neuron-specific enolase. Chromogranin A is used as a serum marker to monitor response to treatment and to detect recurrence.

Treatment is mainly surgical. It includes partial pancreaticoduodenectomy as well as the synchronous or metachronous resection of liver metastases.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a skin lesion as shown in the image below. The lesions were initially small but have now spread to the entire limb and the abdomen. She has a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis despite anticoagulation therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts necrolytic migratory erythema. This skin lesion along with a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent deep vein thrombosis is suggestive of glucagonoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female patient presents with complaints of abdominal pain and foul-smelling, greasy stools for one year. She is known to be diabetic and underwent cholecystectomy one year back. CT scan shows the presence of a tumor in the pancreas. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is somatostatinoma.

Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions. Patients with somatostatinoma usually present with vague abdominal pain along with the triad of:

  • Gallstones - due to bile stasis
  • Diabetes - due to inhibition of insulin secretion
  • Steatorrhea - due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion.

questions.text: A patient with MEN 1 syndrome is diagnosed with VIPoma. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
VIPoma is associated with achlorhydria.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumor (VIPoma) is also known as Verner–Morrison syndrome/WDHA syndrome. WDHA stands for:

  • WD - Watery Diarrhea
  • H – Hypokalemia
  • A – Achlorhydria

Metabolic acidosis from fluid and bicarbonate loss is common in VIPoma.
